com.workmarket.jan20

Class Trial

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.workmarket.jan20.Trial

  • public final class Trial
extends java.lang.Object
    Run a trial of the experiment. Reader note: The control experiment part uses a Callable rather than taking the straight Observable because we wish to ensure that the experimental version is done in parallel with the control. If the API is synchronous, the API might have done all the work already and just wrapped the response it had in an Observable rather than returning an Observable that's linked to some running task in a thread-pool.

    If you want to disable the parallelism, you can use Callables.returning(Object)} to make a Callable from an existing Observable, but really consider why you'd do it first.

    The timer metrics this generates begin when calling the callable to get the value and end either when onCompleted/onError are called from the Observable, or when the callable throws an exception.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  Trial.WhichReturn
      An enum telling the trial which of the two results to return and, by extension, which one is used only for comparison.

      static CallableObservableWrapper IDENTITY_WRAPPER
      If for some reason you require to manually pass in the IDENTITY_WRAPPER to the constructor in lieu of using the 4 argument constructor, this is here so you don't have to.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Trial

        public Trial(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor,
             com.codahale.metrics.MetricRegistry registry,
             java.lang.String metricRootName,
             Trial.WhichReturn whichReturn)
        Create the trial. For the executor, you want something that a) is a limited size pool and b) will reject submissions if the pool is full, rather than blocking. For example, the following will create a pool with one thread ever that has a queue that holds one item, if you try to submit more tasks than can be handled by the queue and pool, it will reject the execution. 
         // change the 1's in the code below to real values! The first two ones, for a fixed pool should be the same value
 // as each other whichever you choose.  The argument to LinkedBlockingQueue is arguable, but small values
 // (like 1) are probably good choices.
  new ThreadPoolExecutor(1, 1, 0, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS, new LinkedBlockingQueue<>(1));

        Why do executors this way? If the code that returns results that is only compared (normally the experiment, but if whichReturn is EXPERIMENT, it would be the control code) is getting stuck or taking too long to run relative to the main line code, we don't want to wedge our clients. Given this only covers the execution of the callable, and the thing which manages the Observable bits may run into it's own issues, but either way, we want the whichReturn'd code to return unimpeded no matter what the non-whichReturn'd code does.

        CAVEAT: the Trial framework here assumes that the control and experiment Observables will only be subscribed to a single time. At the current time, this cannot check the case of multiple subscriptions, and probably has assumptions on cold observables. So rather than having weird things happen, subscribing a second time to the result of doTrial will cause an exception to be thrown. This is also to make it so that, with the above exception, the subscription semantics of the original Observable is preserved.

        Parameters:
        executor - The executor on which to put the callable that will only be used for comparisons.
        registry - The metrics registry in which to create counters.
        metricRootName - The root name from which to make metrics with.
        whichReturn - Which value do you wish to be returned, CONTROL/CONTROL_ONLY or EXPERIMENT?

      • Trial

        public Trial(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor,
             com.codahale.metrics.MetricRegistry registry,
             java.lang.String metricRootName,
             com.google.common.base.Supplier<Trial.WhichReturn> whichReturn)
        Create the trial. Like the other constructor, but provides the ability to pass in wrappers that will be called to wrap the Callable<Observable> of the control and experiment. Useful in cases like where you need things to behave differently due to ThreadLocals and such depending on whether they execute inline or in a background thread.
        Parameters:
        executor - The executor on which to put the callable that will only be used for comparisons.
        registry - The metrics registry in which to create counters.
        metricRootName - The root name from which to make metrics with.
        whichReturn - Supplier of which value you wish to be returned, CONTROL/CONTROL_ONLY or EXPERIMENT?

      • Trial

        public Trial(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor,
             com.codahale.metrics.MetricRegistry registry,
             java.lang.String metricRootName,
             Trial.WhichReturn whichReturn,
             CallableObservableWrapper returnWrapper,
             CallableObservableWrapper compareWrapper)
        Create the trial. Like the other constructor, but provides the ability to pass in wrappers that will be called to wrap the Callable<Observable> of the control and experiment. Useful in cases like where you need things to behave differently due to ThreadLocals and such depending on whether they execute inline or in a background thread.
        Parameters:
        executor - The executor on which to put the callable that will only be used for comparisons.
        registry - The metrics registry in which to create counters.
        metricRootName - The root name from which to make metrics with.
        whichReturn - Which value you wish to be returned, CONTROL/CONTROL_ONLY or EXPERIMENT?
        returnWrapper - Wrapper that can be used to wrap whichever of control or experiment is used to produce the return value.
        compareWrapper - Wrapper that can be used to wrap whichever of control or experiment is only used for comparison.

        public Trial(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService executor,
             com.codahale.metrics.MetricRegistry registry,
             java.lang.String metricRootName,
             com.google.common.base.Supplier<Trial.WhichReturn> whichReturn,
             CallableObservableWrapper returnWrapper,
             CallableObservableWrapper compareWrapper)

Useful in cases like where you need things to behave differently due to ThreadLocals and such depending on whether they execute inline or in a background thread.

        registry - The metrics registry in which to create counters.

    • Method Detail

      • doTrial

        public <T> rx.Observable<T> doTrial(java.util.concurrent.Callable<rx.Observable<T>> control,
                                    java.util.concurrent.Callable<rx.Observable<T>> experiment,
                                    IsEqual<TrialResult<T>> isEqual,
                                    java.lang.String metricName)
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Do a trial.
        Parameters:
        control - A Callable that returns an Observable<T> for the control part of the experiment.
        experiment - A Callable that returns an Observable<T> for the experimental part of the experiment.
        isEqual - An instance used to check equality of the results.
        Returns:
        The result of the control callable.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - the exception that control would throw.

      • makeIsEqual

        Given IsEquals for the throwable and result, return an IsEqual for the whole trial.
        Parameters:

        resultIsEqual - IsEqual for the result.
